topic.title: HP Helion 1.2 Development Platform: Community Installation and Configuration

p.xref: See the Helion 1.0 Development Platform version of this page

body.p: The HP Helion Development Platform currently contains four products: Application Lifecycle Service (ALS), Marketplace Service, Messaging Service and Database Service.
NOTE: If you are installing the HP Helion Development Platform Commercial edition, follow the HP Helion Development Commercial Installation and Configuration instructions instead.
The following topics explain how to install and configure the HP Helion Development Platform.

li.xref: Installing the HP Helion Development Platform

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: The HP Helion Development Platform is installed in the overcloud of HP Helion OpenStack®.

li.p: If you installed HP Helion OpenStack with KVM hypervisor support, you should configure HP StoreVirtual VSA for Block Storage or configure HP 3PAR StoreServ Storage.
If you installed with ESX hypervisor support, then deploy the compute proxy on the ESX hosts and deploy OVSvApp for HP Virtual Cloud Networking.

section.p: The system running the installer needs to have Python 2.7. Most modern operating systems include this as part of their base toolkit. This document is geared toward a Linux operating system but this does not preclude the installer from running on other operating systems with some minor modifications to the command-line statements used in this document.
The installer requires the following packages. If they are not found, it will prompt you to install them.

ul.li: python-dev
libffi-dev
libssl-dev
python-virtualenv
python-pip

codeblock.codeph: sudo apt-get install -y python-dev libffi-dev libssl-dev python-virtualenv python-pip

section.title: Installing the HP Helion Development Platform
section.p: This section describes how to download and install the HP Helion Development Platform.

li.xref: Downloading and unpacking the installation file

required-cleanup.title: Downloading and unpacking the installation file
required-cleanup.p: The installation of the HP Helion Development Platform for the HP Helion OpenStack Community Edition is provided as a small compressed TAR file. The images for the actual services will be downloaded by the installer.
Note: Should you need more assistance during installation, the install script also has a help feature.

codeblock.codeph: ./DevelopmentPlatform_Setup.sh -h

li.p: Register and download the package from the HP Helion Development Platform (HDN)
Before you begin the installation, unpack the tar file.

codeblock.codeph: tar -zxvf hp_helion_devplatform_community.tar.gz.csu

li.p: Run this command to create and populate a dev-platform-installer directory.

codeblock.codeph: cd dev-platform-installer

li.p: If your network uses a proxy, it may be necessary to set the proxy shell variable.

codeblock.codeph: export https_proxy=<ip address or url of https proxy>

li.p: Run this command to prepare the installer and ensure prerequisites are met.

codeblock.codeph: ./DevelopmentPlatform_Setup.sh -p {admin_user_password} -a {auth_host_ip_address}

li.p: Optionally, you can specify the Username, Tenant and Region at this time. By default the Username is admin, the Tenant Name is admin and the Region is regionOne.

codeblock.codeph: ./DevelopmentPlatform_Setup.sh -p {admin_user_password} -a {auth_host_ip_address} -u {username} -t {tenant_name} -r {region_name}

li.p: Once the installation is complete, you should see output similar to the following:

codeblock.codeph: 2014-06-17 16:53:19.765 INFO Install Complete

section.title: Install the Messaging Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the HP Helion Development Platform Messaging service.

li.p: Open Horizon and login as the Admin user. Then click on the Admin panel in Horizon and select Development Platform. Finally, click Configure Services.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HP Download Network (HDN).
If you do not have an account, click the Sign-up button.
As the Admin user, in the Configure Services panel locate the Messaging item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.

required-cleanup.title: Install the Horizon UI
required-cleanup.p: This section describes how to install the Horizon UI for the Messaging service.

required-cleanup.title: Step 1: Retrieve the Messaging Service Update from CODN
required-cleanup.p: Use the Helion Development Platform UI to check CODN for a new Service Update for the messaging service.

NOTE: Be sure that the "Admin" project is checked (check mark beside it) from the Project selector before you check for service updates. The Project selector is located at the top of the page to the right of the OpenStack logo.
If there is a new Service Update for the messaging service, retrieve it from CODN. This will retrieve the Messaging package from CODN and push it into a container in Swift within your local cloud.

required-cleanup.title: Step 2: Install the Messaging Service Update
Preparation
required-cleanup.p: You will need the following pieces of information in order to run the Messaging Service Update.

row.entry: The IP address of the base node for your Helion installation.
The IP address of the seed node for your Helion installation.
The username of a cloud admin that has rights to perform an HDP Messaging Service Update.
The password of a cloud admin that has rights to perform an HDP Messaging Service Update.
The private key file for the **heat-admin** user. Usually available within the root user account on the seed node here: **~/.ssh/id_rsa**

The Swift container that contains the messaging service update.
Defaults to **cue-dashboard-horizon-ui**.

The filename of the messaging service update.
Typically can be found inside the above container in Swift.

required-cleanup.title: Let's get to it!
required-cleanup.p: a) SSH to the seed node of your cloud:

codeblock.codeph:
# SSH to the base node ssh USERNAME@BASE_NODE_IP
# Become root sudo su (will prompt for the PASSWORD)
# SSH to seed node ssh SEED_NODE_IP

required-cleanup.p: b) Ensure your environment has the proper credentials to perform the download from Swift:

codeblock.codeph: # Source the overcloud credentials to reach Swift export TE_DATAFILE="/root/tripleo/ce_env.json" source /root/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/overcloudrc

required-cleanup.p: c) Use the Swift client to download the Service Update:

codeblock.codeph:
# List the contents of the Swift container swift list cue-dashboard-horizon-ui
# Take note of the name of the file within the container # ex: SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME.tar.gz
# Download the installation file swift download CONTAINER_NAME SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME

required-cleanup.p: d) Once the file is downloaded, unzip/tar the file:

codeblock.codeph: tar -zxvf SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME.tar.gz

required-cleanup.p: e) Go into the newly created folder and execute the install script, passing in the location of the private key of the heat-admin account:

codeblock.codeph:
# Source undercloud creds from the same location as the overcloudrc source /root/tripleo/tripleo-incubator/undercloudrc
# Fire up the install! cd SERVICE_UPDATE_FILENAME ./install.sh HEAT_ADMIN_KEY

li.p: In the Helion Development Platform UI , click the Configure Service button to configure the messaging service and wait for the configuration step to complete.
Log out of the Horizon dashboard.
Log back into the Horizon dashboard as a non-admin user and click on the Messaging panel under the current project to begin using the messaging service.

section.title: Install the Database Service
section.p: This section provides details on installing the HP Helion Development Platform Database service.

required-cleanup.title: Prerequisites
required-cleanup.p: Before installing, make sure the following prerequisites are met:

required-cleanup.title: Configure the Service Network
required-cleanup.p: The database service needs an additional network for administrative purposes. This network is currently not used in Community edition but must exist in order for Database Service to properly install.

li.p: Open Horizon and login as the Admin user.
Click Project.
Click Network and then the Networks tab.
Click Create Network.
In Network Name field, enter SVC for the name of the network.
Click Next.
In the Network Address field, enter a CIDR that does not conflict with other services (such as: 172.10.0.0/24).
Click Next.
Click Create.

required-cleanup.title: Check Project Quotas
required-cleanup.p: The database service will be installed into the Admin project of the Helion OpenStack overcloud. The Admin project must have sufficient quotas available for the service to use. To check existing quota availability, log in to Horizon as the Admin user and open the Overview panel under the Compute tab.
For the Community edition, the database service requires that the Admin project have the following quotas available:

In addition to the quotas mentioned above, for every database instance that is created by a user, the necessary resources to create that instance will be deducted from the Admin project quota. The user's Database service quota will also be affected.

li.p: Open Horizon and login as the Admin user. Then click on the Admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform panel under Admin. Then click the Configure Services sub-panel.
Click the Connect button on the Configure Services panel and enter your username and password for the HP Download Network (HDN). If you do not have an account, click Sign-up.
In the Configure Services panel locate the Database Service item in the Configure Services table and select Download Service and wait for the download to complete.

required-cleanup.title: Step 3: Configure the Service

li.p: In the Configure Services panel in the Helion Development Platform UI, click the Configure Service button to begin configuration of the service. In the configuration dialog, specify the following configuration options:

ul.li: Service User Password (Required) - The password for the Admin user that is currently logged in. This password MUST match the password used to log in to Horizon.
Key Pair (Required) - Key Pair to install on all instances created as part of the database service. The public key can be used by an admin to get SSH access to all instances.
External Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has external network access. For HP Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named ext-net .
Provider Network (Required) - Network Name for the network that has network access to cloud infrastructure services. For HP Helion OpenStack Commercial Edition this network is named SVC.
NTP Server IP - IP Address to an NTP server to use if instances will not have outbound access to the internet.
Logstash RabbitMQ IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Logstash RabbitMQ Password (Required) - Specify the password for the RabbitMQ Server publishing to the central Logstash server.
Ephemeral CA Password (Required) - Specify the password for the Ephemeral CA server.
Ephemeral CA IP Address (Required) - Specify the IP address of Ephemeral CA server.
Volume Type (Required) - The volume type to use when creating database instances.

li.p: Enable HA - Specify if the database service is to be set up in a high-availability (HA) configuration. If selected, each component of the service will have three instances created and active at all times.
After all configuration options have been provided, select the Configure button to complete the configuration step. Wait for the configuration step to complete and the status to change to Configured.

required-cleanup.p: The following steps will configure HAProxy to receive and forward HTTP requests to the VM that hosts the REST API endpoint for Marketplace. To perform these steps you must be connected to the overcloud node.

li.p: Identify the API server IPs on the SVC network. You should have as many API servers (and IPs) as you have Availability Zones in your Helion OpenStack install.

codeblock.codeph: nova list | awk '/trove[0-9]*_api/{ print $4,"\t", substr($12,5) }'

li.p: Identify the Virtual IP used by the controller nodes to be able to load balance the Helion OpenStack services:

codeblock.codeph: keystone endpoint-list | awk '/8779/{ print $6 }' | egrep -o "[0-9]+.[0-9]+.[0-9]+.[0-9]+"

li.p: Update configuration on each of the Helion OpenStack controller nodes by connecting to the controller and doing the following:
a. Edit the /etc/haproxy/manual/paas.cfg file and add the following lines. The last line should be repeated once for each API server identified in step 1.

codeblock.codeph: listen trove_api bind <Virtual IP from step 2>:8779 option httpchk GET / server trove-trove<n>_api-<uniqueid> <API server n's IP Address> check inter 2000 rise 2 fall 5 check-ssl ca-file /etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt

li.p: b. Edit the /etc/iptables/rules.v4 file and add to it:

codeblock.codeph: -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT

li.p: c. Run the following command as root:

codeblock.codeph: sudo iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 8779 -j ACCEPT

li.p: d. Reload the haproxy service configuration

codeblock.codeph: sudo service haproxy reload

li.p: Log out from the Horizon dashboard. Log back into the Horizon dashboard as a non-admin user and click on the Database Service panel under the current Project to being using Database Service.

li.p: Download the Vertica package.
a) Open Horizon and log in as the "admin" user. Then click on the admin panel in Horizon and select the Development Platform Panel under Admin. Then click on the Configure Services sub-panel.

required-cleanup.p: Refer to the following topics if you experience problems with the installation.

required-cleanup.title: Service is stuck in download
required-cleanup.p: There are situations in which a download will not complete. One cause which is documented, is because the tmp directory ran out of space. There is a prerequisite to mount the tmp directory to a larger partition. If you have completed this step and the download is still failing, then we will need to reset the download. In the current release, this requires a manual process.

As the admin user, in the Admin project, click on Project, then Object Store. Open the sherpa-cache folder and delete the wscatalog.<id> folder which contains the cached download. The service should now be available to download again.
